citeinfo.origin: Bernardin, Lochmueller & Associates (BLA) (data creator and compiler)
citeinfo.title: RELIGIOUS_CENTERS_USGS_BLA_IN: Religious Centers in Indiana (United States Geological Survey and Bernardin, Lochmueller & Associates, 1:24,000, Point Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit: This data set was compiled by personnel of Bernardin, Lochmueller & Associates (BLA) from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Geographic Names Information System (GNIS), USGS topographic map review, and locating addresses found on various religious listing web sites. To find out more about the USGS, GNIS visit http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/index.html. Web sites used to obtain address listings for additional listings include - Dharma Web <http://www.dharmaweb.org/index.php/Indiana>, Jewish Finder <http://www.ujc.org/ir_LL_category.html?state=in>, and The Church of Jesus Christ Latter-day Saints <http://www.mormon.org/worshipwithus/1,20864,,00.html>.

descript.abstract: A data set showing the locations of religious centers and places of worship in Indiana. The base file for this effort was the USGS Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) data for churches current to 20070125. In 2001, BLA ground truthed churches in the current GNIS data for a large area in southern Indiana. Many locations were added. These locations were checked against the new 2007 GNIS data for duplicates, and were added to the dataset. In order to find additional locations and locations for facilities for non-Christian religions, the internet was searched for lists of locations for various religions. Addresses found were located using Google Maps <http://maps.google.com/> and plotted in GIS using aerials.
descript.purpose: To provide the locations of religious centers and places of worship in Indiana as a GIS layer. While the base file is 2007 GNIS data, it has been expanded with locations obtained by ground truthing and locations of facilities for non-Christian religions.

idinfo.native: ESRI ArcGIS 9.2 shapefile format, approximately 1.43 Mb

attracc.attraccr:
Data attributes are accurate to the information source.
The following was excerpted from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) metadata -
"During Phase I data compilation, a random sample of 10% of the entries in the system were visually verified against the compilation source data (large-scale USGS topographic maps) to ensure an accuracy rate of at least 95%. Subsequent data compilation and input processes ensure accuracy with programmed validation checks for format and content, visual examination, and spot checks of data."
BLA 2001 ground truthing data is believed to be very accurate. Points were marked on aerial printouts in the field and placed on digital aerials in the GIS.
BLA 2007 internet locations relies on Google Maps to locate listed addresses. No confidence level is provided by Google Maps, but as each point was digitzed, the location was checked with GIS files for roads and county and others. Becasue of this cross checking and individual point placement by an analyst, the locatitons are beleived to be accurate, although no testing has been performed.

dataqual.logic:
Some sites may be duplicated with position differences.
The following was excerpted from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) metadata -
"During Phase I data compilation, a random sample of 10% of the entries in the system were visually verified against the compilation source data (large-scale USGS topographic maps) to ensure an accuracy rate of at least 95%. Subsequent data compilation and input processes ensure accuracy with programmed validation checks for format and content, visual examination, and spot checks of data."
dataqual.complete:
This data set contains the records from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) and is further supplemented by locating address found on web site listings for churches and other religious centers. Additional records in southwestern Indiana were located by field review and topographic map review in areas associated with Interstate 69 studies.
The following was excerpted from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) metadata -
"Subsequent to the original data compilation process, which was taken primarily from Federal maps, the GNIS has become dependent on input from Federal, State, county, and local government agencies and other approved sources. The completeness, currency, and accuracy of the data varies by area depending on the quality and timeliness of that input. Accordingly, the Geographic Names Project actively seeks to expand partnerships with Government agencies at all levels and other interested organizations. The latest tools and methodologies are being applied, including web map and feature services, and joint or linked web applications, to ensure that local data are properly represented in the GNIS and through the GNIS to all Federal agencies and to the public. Feature additions or corrections are accepted for consideration from any source, and when validated by appropriate agencies, will be entered into the database. Local and State agencies are encouraged to submit data and to participate in the GNIS partnership program. Non-government organizations with valuable data are considered on a case basis. Data entered into the GNIS immediately is available to all web services and applications dependent on it. For additional information or to request user accounts for entry and edit of production data and web seminar training, contact gnis_manager@usgs.gov."
BLA field review locations were limited to areas associated with a proposed Interstate, which will be located in Southern Indiana. More additions are present in southern Indiana counties.

horizpa.horizpar:
Horizontal accuracy is dependant on the USGS data source and supplemental data was positioned using Google Maps <http://maps.google.com/>. Large scale use and precision applications are not recommended.
The following was excerpted from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) metadata -
"Accuracy of these digital data are based upon the use of printed or electronic source graphics which are compiled to meet National Map Accuracy Standards. Comparison to the graphic source is used as control to assess digital positional accuracy."

citeinfo.title: IN_DECI.SHP, Geographic Names Information system, Indiana Feature Names
CHURCHES_USGS_BLA_IN: Church Locations in Indiana (United States Geological Survey, 1:24000, Point Shapefile)

srcinfo.srccontr: Names, attributes, and coordinate information of additional churches

procstep.procdesc: The internet was used perform Google searches to locate directories of address of non-Christian religions, Mormon (CJCLDS) facilities, Jehovah's Witness facilities, Amish churches, Mennonite Churches, and Quaker Churches. Web sites used included - Dharma Web <http://www.dharmaweb.org/index.php/Indiana>, Jewish Finder <http://www.ujc.org/ir_LL_category.html?state=in>, and The Church of Jesus Christ Latter-day Saints <http://www.mormon.org/worshipwithus/1,20864,,00.html>. The web site <http://www.churchangel.com/>, was used to locate additional Christian church addresses in select counties. The counties were - Bartholomew, Benton, Brown, Clark, Clay, Crawford, Daviess, Dearborn, Decatur, Dubois, Floyd, Franklin, Gibson, Greene, Harrison, Jackson, Jefferson, Jennings, Knox, Lawrence, Martin, Monroe, Morgan, Ohio, Orange, Owen, Perry, Pike, Posey, Ripley, Scott, Sullivan, Switzerland, Vanderburgh, Vigo, Warrick, and Washington. Addresses were located using Google Map <http://maps.google.com/>, then located in the GIS using an aerial and Tiger Line files for the roads. The locations were made into a temporary shapefile.

GNIS feature data for Indiana was downloaded from the USGS, GNIS web site, <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/index.html>. Data tables were converted to a shapefile using the primary latitude and primary longitude as reference. Churches in Indiana were extracted by attribute/location query from all features. The file was transformed from geographic to UTM 16, NAD83.
All features in the file "CHURCHES_USGS_BLA_IN.SHP" that were noted as being "Added" in the "Edits" field were extracted from the dataset and saved as a temporary file called "CHURCHES_BLA_I69.shp".

Each temporary file was compared using location queries and "intersect" to locate any points between files within 3 meters of each other. A few duplicates were found and resolved. A location query was used to find any points falling outside the Indiana boundary. One was located and deleted. The three temporary shapefiles, CHURCHES_BLAADDED_2007.SHP, GNIS_20070125.SHP, and CHURCHES_BLA_I69.SHP were merged together.
This metadata file was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit, v.2.6.1) and MP (Metadata Parser, v.2.7.1) software written by Peter N. Schwitzer (U.S. Geological Survey).

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are software generated

edom.edomvd: Data added in 2001 as part of I-69 Corridor studies
Data added in 2007 from addresses found on web sites
Data downloaded from the GNIS web site current to 20070125

distinfo.distliab:
No claims to accuracy are made on these data. It is intended to be used only for general planning purposes. Detailed planning or analysis will require more accurate data.

metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is intended to accompany the data set identified and received from the BLA. It should not to be altered or summarized. BLA does not support secondary distribution. If this data set was received from anyone besides the BLA, this metadata file and the data set it describes may lack integrity.
